results.title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Fans Are Rediscovering a 40-Year-Old Documentary
results.abstract: “The Day After Trinity,” made available without a subscription until August, shot to the top of the Criterion Channel’s most-watched films.

media.caption: Decades before the movie “Oppenheimer,” J. Robert Oppenheimer and his work on the atomic bomb were the subject of the Academy Award-nominated documentary “The Day After Trinity.”

results.adx_keywords: Pop and Rock Music;Content Type: Personal Profile;Fans (Persons);Matthews, Dave;Dave Matthews Band
results.title: Why Are Dave Matthews Band Fans So Loyal?
results.abstract: Some have spent thousands of dollars and traveled hundreds of miles to see them since their summer tours started in the early ’90s.

media.caption: For a certain set of music enthusiasts born between 1970 to 2000, the Dave Matthews Band is synonymous with summer. Here, the crowd at their show this year at New York’s Forest Hills Stadium.

results.title: ‘A Dangerous Combination’: Teenagers’ Accidents Expose E-Bike Risks
results.abstract: The e-bike industry is booming, but many vehicles are not legal for teenagers, and accidents are on the rise.

media.caption: A memorial for Brodee Champlain Kingman on the corner of El Camino Real and Santa Fe Drive in Encinitas, Calif. Brodee was killed last month in an e-bike traffic accident.

results.title: What ‘Oppenheimer’ Doesn’t Tell You About the Trinity Test
results.abstract: As a new generation of Americans learns about the world’s first nuclear test, the people who lived through it are being left out of the story again.

media.caption: A sign once carried by a victim of radiation from the 1945 atomic bomb test in New Mexico on display at the New Mexico History Museum in Santa Fe in 2019.

results.title: ‘We Can Never Forgive This’: In Odesa, Attacks Stoke Hatred of Russia
results.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia views Odesa as a culturally important part of his nation. But many in the Ukrainian city reject the connection and view the country that has been attacking it with loathing.

results.adx_keywords: Archaeology and Anthropology;Roman Civilization;Theater;Christians and Christianity;Building (Construction);Historic Buildings and Sites;internal-storyline-no;Nero (37-68 AD);Pliny the Elder (24-79 AD);Four Seasons Hotels Ltd;Roman Catholic Church;Rome (Italy);Italy
results.title: Excavations Uncover Hints of Nero’s Theater in Rome, and Much More
results.abstract: A dig at a palace set to become a hotel has unearthed traces of a theater that archaeologists hypothesize was built by Nero, the emperor with a disputed reputation for tyranny and debauchery.

media.caption: An archaeological dig at a Renaissance palazzo in Rome brought to light traces of the first-century theater that Emperor Nero built to indulge his inner artist.

results.title: A Summer Spectacle Where Fireflies Are the Guiding Light
results.abstract: Bill and Mary-Ellen McDonald host firefly viewing parties, hoping to inspire their neighbors to stop using pesticides and consider rewilding their lawns.

media.caption: In New Canaan, Conn., Bill and Mary-Ellen McDonald have created a sanctuary for fireflies. This composite image is made up of long-exposure photos to show star trails.

results.title: Judge Dismisses Trump’s $475 Million Defamation Suit Against CNN
results.abstract: The network’s statements were opinion, the ruling said, and did not support a claim of libel and slander.

media.caption: Donald J. Trump’s lawsuit said CNN’s statements in reference to his efforts to overturn the 2020 election results were tantamount to comparing him to Adolf Hitler and Nazism.
media.copyright: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

results.title: The Secret History of Gun Rights: How Lawmakers Armed the N.R.A.

results.title: Fighting for Anthony: The Struggle to Save Portland, Oregon
results.abstract: The city has long grappled with street homelessness and a shortage of housing. Now fentanyl has turned a perennial problem into a deadly crisis and a challenge to the city’s progressive identity.

media.caption: The city has been stepping up efforts to take down tents and relocate people to shelters. But many of them simply packed up their belongings and pitched tents elsewhere.

results.title: New York City Had a Migrant Crisis. It Hired a Covid Expert to Help.
results.abstract: DocGo, a medical services firm, has moved hundreds of asylum seekers outside the city as part of its no-bid $432 million contract. Many say they have been threatened and lied to.

media.caption: Although much of DocGo’s expertise is in providing mobile medical services, it was hired by New York City to help with its influx of migrants.

results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;Slavery (Historical);Deaths (Obituaries);Research;Writing and Writers;Yellin, Jean Fagan;Jacobs, Harriet (1813-97)
results.title: Jean Fagan Yellin, Who Uncovered a Slavery Tale’s True Author, Dies at 92
results.abstract: Her research proved that a 19th-century book presumed to be a novel by a white woman was actually an autobiography by a formerly enslaved Black woman.

media.caption: Jean Yellin in the 1980s. She came across “Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl” while writing her dissertation and developed a hunch that the book was autobiographical.
